intro: Mirabilis tenuiloba, commonly known as the narrow-leaf four-o'clock, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Onagraceae and is characterized by its slender, lance-shaped leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that bloom in the evening. The plant produces bright red or orange flowers, which are typically fragrant and attract pollinators such as moths and beetles. It is a herbaceous perennial that thrives in well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade. Its botanical features make it a popular choice for ornamental gardening and ecological studies.
